SOURCE)."),a.default.createElement(n.default,{variant:"body1",className:"MainPara"},"Open Source projects have changed the world and improved the lives of many. They, however, face one main problem: Economic viability. The majority of value created in Open Source is captured by “middlemen” corporations such as GitHub. The lack of funding dissuades project maintainers from sustaining development, discourages developers from contributing, and deprives users of useful open software. 80% of all Open Source projects are abandoned."),a.default.createElement(n.default,{variant:"body1",className:"MainPara"},"The Source protocol is used to signal and coordinate services between investors, project maintainers, developers and the platform, and is intended to serve as an open standard for developing Open Source Software projects."),a.default.createElement(n.default,{variant:"body1",className:"MainPara"},"The protocol captures network effects by creating financial incentives to drive all parties on the network to coordinate their actions towards an optimal outcome (building great software). Establishing and maintaining an open standard is a coordination problem that adds operational overhead for all contributing parties; coordination can be especially challenging when each party has different needs and financial incentives. Protocol tokens can align financial incentives and offset costs associated with organizing multiple parties around a single technical standard. Token staking can be used as a voting mechanism for decentralized governance.
